abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project was
            satisfactory. The relevance of the project's policy
            measures are reflected by subsequent structural adjustments
            loans (SAL), which further strengthen the reform program.
            Both performances, the Bank and Borrower's, are
            reviewed in terms of what reasonably transpired as a result
            of the financial crisis, and what would have been a better
            course in retrospect. Similarly, the lessons learned are
            reviewed within that context, suggesting that both the Bank,
            and Korean authorities should have maintained closer ties,
            to better anticipate the events leading to the crisis.
            Although the Bank customized the operation to meet the
            urgency of the situation, earlier involvement in discussions
            with the Government, and the International Monetary Fund
            (IMF), should have taken place. The potential to maximize
            negotiation results, once stabilization measures are
            established, could be emphasized to achieve reforms;
            however, any additional conditionality should be taken into
            consideration, for the program's effectiveness could be
            well in danger. The Bank should have the capacity for
            management portfolio risk, to assess risk adjustment capital
            allocation. However, careful consistency with the
            Bank's business, i.e., development institution, should
            be maintained; hence, a subsequent policy specifies this
            concern, in the form of special SALs.

5085878.majtheme: Public sector governance,Social protection and risk management,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Economic Reconstruction Project
            supports the Republic of Korea's rapid initiation of a
            program of actions, objectives, and policies designed to
            achieve economic reconstruction through long-term
            stabilization of the Korean economy. The project will
            provide balance of payments assistance in Korea in
            implementing a program of financial and real sector reforms.
            The loan supports government efforts to deal with the
            immediate liquidity crisis as well as support to the
            government's medium-term reform program. For the
            immediate future, the package consists of satisfactory
            macroeconomic management, remedial actions related to the
            suspension of merchant banks, recapitalization of impaired
            commercial banks, improvements in the operation of the Korea
            Asset Management Corporation, and the creation of a
            consolidated independent supervisory agency. While promoting
            steps to immediately improve financial competition and
            disclosure, the program also lays out an agreed agenda for
            broader financial and real sector reforms, focusing on; a)
            financial regulation and supervision of capital markets; b)
            corporate governance; c) competition policies; and d) labor
            market adjustments and social sector safety nets.
